Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: crown; Collapsing, localized; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Ski tracks on slope; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes:
Last avalanche profile for the season:
Done at the crown of a windblown slab avalanche from 21.04.2022. Warm temps have melted the surface slab and the remaining crown is no more than 30-40cm. The warm temperatures since then have stabalized this surface slab, and it is now well bonded with the layer below it. It does not slide during the compression test and it probably unlilely to slide from a skier.
Trying to trigger the slide right above the crown (I stepped on top of it and was right on its edge) with skis required many jumps.
Isothermal snowpack of 0 degrees celsius - warm temperatures and lots of melting. The surface snow slides a bit when turning with skis on this steep section, but this is only the very top part that has become soaked with water.
Seems to be unlikely to trigger something deeper with the current state of the snowpack - the layers below are well bonded and progressively become less and less wet and more firm. Another potential weak spot is around 1 meter from the surface, where after the compression test, sticking the shovel in the back and attempting to remove the column with my hands resulted in a breakup. At first the entire column started to be isolated (down to 180 cm from the surface, where the snowpit ends) but then a breakup was observed around a meter down. Still - this is quite deep and not likely to be triggered at the moment.
Despite this - it is good to follow typical spring skiing rules and ski early in the day, before the water has a chance to soak the snowpack deeper down and potentially activate something more serious.
Fjlls, TL, microterrng, temp profil
Solen gassade rakt mot snytan. Lssluttning, ingen vind....
Fjlls, ALP, tempprofil

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit dug in a Ski Area; Pit is representative of backcountry; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Warm temps between storms formed 2 crusts within the new snow. Both crusts show more bonding and rounding above and below although the upper crust fails under palm pressure. The layer of concern at 25 down, under the uppermost crust, showed signs of rounding.
vre del av l sluttning
SZ av brant rnna, lsida med stor fetch
SZ ovan klipporna ner till tarfaladalen, sluttningen tar sol tidigt p morgonen s legat mnga timmar i sol utan att bli vldigt moist.

njekjan saman ringd og gegnum frosinn, slinsur og grfir strir MFpc milli, efst var meira los kristllum vntanlega vegna hrifa slar og hita sem hefur veri. 74 cm dpi var ykkt slag sem samsvarar vi rennslisflt sem fli fll 2022.04.13. ekkert kom fram testum CTN. Talsvert um togsprungur efst hengjum allstaar svinu en a er sjanlegt a mjg mikill snjr er vesturvsandi hlum eftir langvarandi veur r austurttum og m gera r fyrir flum r essum hengjum egar a koma flugir hlku kafflar.
Snflt ovanfr klippor. Strre WHUMF innan profilen-troligt att det saboterade testet. Sg ut som FC ovanp skaren. Arbetade inknuten.

Pit_Observation.activities: Pit is adjacent to avalanche: other;
Collapsing, localized; Cracking; Recent avalanche activity on similar slopes; Recent avalanche activity on different slopes; We skied slope;
Pit_Observation.pitNotes: Two large whumps were observed while traveling on a south aspect @2670. The layer collapsed enough to create large shooting cracks and visibly dropped ~2cm.
Dug into the top 90 cm of snow. New snow was top 40 cm. The March 5th dust layer occurred from 17-14 cm up from the bottom of where we dug (148 to 145 in the total snowpack).
